doc.title: Deutsche Bank Research
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Model Update Following Q225 ResultsModel Update Following Q225 Results_2025-08-29

passages.text: High Yield Corporates Healthcare

There are numerous moving parts to this story. Some of the biggest considerations relate to the potential timing and impact of generic competition on Xifaxan, litigation, various considerations related to B&L, FCF, other operating trends including Solta performance, the potential contribution of Red- C (if approved) / other launches, future liability management, potential impacts from tariffs/transfer pricing, and other. BHCCN made significant progress on upcoming maturities with its Q225 refinancing, but we note there is more to go (roughly \(4.3 billion in 2028). We believe pipeline products could prove to be an important part to the story in the out years. We rate BHCCN's bonds Buy but we appreciate the uncertainties and potential volatility in the story. If BHCCN hits our 2025 estimates (consolidated), EBITDA would be\) 3,472 mn, and this would put consolidated net leverage at 5.6x. BHCCN's guidance for consolidated 2025 EBITDA is \(3,485 - 3,635 mn\).
Miles Highsmith Research Analyst +1- 212- 250- 1606

There are a number of risks to our rating, the most significant of which include the potential spin of B&L, Xifaxan competition, high leverage, litigation, tariffs, technicals, and other. If one or some of these risks came to pass or developed a higher probability, bonds could underperform.
Figure 1: Select Outstanding Issues

Deutsche Bank Securities Inc.

IMPORTANT RESEARCH DISCLOSURES AND ANALYST CERTIFICATIONS LOCATED IN APPENDIX 1. UNTIL 19th MARCH 2021 INCOMPLETE DISCLOSURE INFORMATION MAY HAVE BEEN DISPLAYED, PLEASE SEE APPENDIX 1 FOR FURTHER DETAILS.

Key Points:Consolidated Q225 ResultsBHCCN reported consolidated Q225 EBITDA (this is EBITDA less minority interest) of \(842 mm versus\) 798 mm in Q224. By our calculations this put consolidated net leverage at \(6.0x\) and this down from \(6.2x\) for LTM 3/31/25. Due to certain accounting adjustments (as part of the Q322 exchanges), certain debt balances per the balance sheet incorporate additional items. As such, the debt balance per the balance sheet is higher than the principal balances. By our calculations per BHCCN's Q225 slides, the accounting changes added roughly \(588 mm to the debt balances at 6/30/25, which had roughly a 0.2x impact on consolidated PF leverage. Based on this math, net leverage would be roughly 5.8x - which is 6.0x less 0.2x - using principal debt balances.

Q225 Bausch Health (excluding B&L) RevenueBHCCN reported Q225 revenue of \(+5\%\) on an organic basis excluding B&L. By division, Salix was \(+12\%\) organic (Xifaxan \(+10\%\) ), International \(+1\%\) , Solta \(+26\%\) , and Diversified was \(- 13\%\) . B&L revenue was \(+3\%\) .

Q225 Bausch Health (excluding B&L) EBITDAPer its earnings presentation, Q225 Bausch Health (excluding B&L) EBITDA was \(676 mm, up 10\%\) from Q224. Note that this EBITDA does not subtract minority interest, and we believe this is the appropriate way to look at EBITDA as the bulk of the minority interest relates to the minority ownership of B&L. For LTM 6/30/25, by our calculations EBITDA was \(2,687 mm\) by the same methodology.

2025 Bausch Health (excluding B&L) EBITDA GuidanceBHCCN reiterated its 2025 EBITDA guidance for Bausch Health (excluding B&L) \(2,625 - 2,725 mm, or\) 2,675 mm at the mid- point. For perspective, FY24 EBITDA was \(2,553 mm and FY23 EBITDA was\) 2,356 mm. It's our understanding that none of these subtract minority interest. Revenue guidance for Bausch Health (excluding B&L) of \(4,950 - 5,100 mm for 2025 implies organic growth of +2\%\) to \(+6\%\) versus 2024. We note that consolidated Bausch Health raised EBITDA guidance by \$10 mm, and this was essentially all attributable to B&L.

In its Q225 slide presentation, BHCCN indicated that total Bausch Health (excluding B&L) net debt was roughly \(14,655 mm at 6/30/25. These debt balances are based on principal balances and as such do not add the accounting adjustments noted above in the consolidated debt balances.

Based on \(4,655 mm of debt at Bausch Health (excluding B&L), and using our calculated LTM 6/30/25 EBITDA of\) 2,687 mm (which does not subtract minority interest) at Bausch Health (excluding B&L), we come up with net leverage of 5.5x. This compares to 5.6x for LTM 3/31/25 using the same methodology.

Regarding tariffs more broadly, it's our understanding that BHCCN does most of its manufacturing in regions where it operates ing in Latin America, Mexico, and Colombia. Most of the European business is done by CMG or BHCCN's facility in Poland. Regarding Xifaxan specifically, BHCCN stated that the API comes from Italy and the manufacturing comes from (but for U.S. customs purposes it is treated as an Italian import).
Xifaxan revenue was reported \(+10\%\) in Q225 (TRx \(+6\%\) ).
We believe BHCCN could again consider the sale of B&L at a future time, and this would depend on the segment's results as well as the valuations in the market.

BHCCN has received P4 notices from Amneal (received 2/28/24, filed infringement suit 4/5/24), Zydus (received notice 8/15/24, filed infringement suit 9/27/24), Cipla (received notice 9/18/24, filed infringement suit 11/1/24) Carnegie (received notice 10/1/24, filed infringement suit 11/7/24, and settled on 6/12/25 per a confidential agreement), Mylan (received 2/11/25, filed infringement suit 3/26/25), SABA (received 2/20/25, filed infringement suit 4/4/25), and Alkerm (received notice 4/28/25, filed infringement suit 6/10/25). Based on BHCCN's infringement suit against Amneal filed 4/5/24, we believe the 30- month stay would extend through October 2026. Related to Norwich, in a letter 1/10/25 the FDA granted tentative approval to Norwich for its second ANDA. The FDA granted tentative approval on Amneal's ANDA on 1/16/25. As a reminder, BHCCN's previous settlement agreements with Sun, Sandoz, and TEVA would give these companies non- exclusive licenses to the IP related to Xifaxan 550 mg tablets beginning 1/1/28.

Based on our very rough analysis that incorporates numerous assumptions, we believe Red- C (if approved) could bring in peak revenue in the hundreds of millions of dollars (and potentially more). We have made assumptions around market size, dose, price, duration, market capture, international penetration, and others. It's our belief that, if approved, in most cases Red- C would be prescribed by the same doctor that prescribes Xifaxan. BHCCN continues to expect a phase 3 read- out on Red- C in early 2026. And we suspect, if approved, that BHCCN could launch Red- C in 2027.

We do not believe BHCCN repurchased any bonds in the open market in Q225. Based on our math, BHCCN repurchased \(305mm\) principal of \(9\%\) bonds due 2025 during Q224. And BHCCN repurchased \(115mm\) of 2025 unsecured notes and \(135mm\) of 2026 unsecured notes during Q124. BHCCN previously reported that it repurchased \(464mm\) of bonds in Q422 for \(250mm\) ( \(361mm\) of the \(464mm\) were 2028- 2031 maturities, and this implies average price of 56). BHCCN also previously reported that that it bought in \(481mm\) of 2028- 2031 bonds in the open market during Q222 for \(300mm\) (implies average price of 62). During Q322, BHCCN completed the exchange of roughly \(5,594mm\) of debt into new secured debt with a principal balance of \(3,125mm\) , capturing a discount of roughly \(2,469mm\) ( \(3,469mm\) excluding debt at its unrestricted subsidiary).

Liquidity and MaturitiesPer its Q225 earnings presentation, BHCCN (excluding B&L) had \(15 \text{mm}\) of debt maturities in 2025, \(632 \text{mm}\) in 2026, \(673 \text{mm}\) in 2027, and \(4,309 \text{mm}\) in 2028. At 6/30/25 BHCCN had \(1,727 \text{mm}\) of unrestricted cash (consolidated), and by our calculations \(1,536 \text{mm}\) of availability on its facilities after LCs, for total liquidity (consolidated) of \(3,263 \text{mm}\) .

Bausch Health (excluding B&L) reiterated its 2025 guidance for revenue of \(4,950 - 5,100 \text{mm}\) and EBITDA of \(2,625 - 2,725 \text{mm}\) . BHCCN also maintained its CF Ops guidance for 2025 of \(150 \text{mm}\) to \(825 - 875 \text{mm}\) . Note that our projections are for the consolidated company (and not Bausch Health excluding B&L), and as such compares to EBITDA guidance of \(3,485 - 3,635 \text{mm}\) . If BHCCN hits our numbers, 2025 EBITDA would be \(3,472 \text{mm}\) , and this would put consolidated net leverage at \(5.6x\) . Note this is based on balance sheet debt, which is higher than the principal amount of debt (by roughly \(0.2x\) ), and making this adjustment 2025 consolidated net leverage would be roughly \(5.4x\) ( \(5.6x - 0.2x = 5.4x\) ). The following table illustrates BHCCN's summary financials and our projections through 2025.
Figure 2: Bausch Health Companies (BHC)

Buy: These bonds are expected to outperform other issues in the sector/industry group over the next three to six- month period.

Hold: These bonds are fairly valued currently. If owned, no need to sell, but we await events/releases/conditions that would make the bond attractive enough for us to upgrade. In the interim, the bond will likely perform as well as the average issue in the sector/industry group.
Sell: There exists a significant likelihood that these bonds will underperform relative to other issues in their sector/industry group, at least over the next three months.

Some trade ideas for equities are listed as Catalyst Calls on the Research Website (https://research.db.com/Research/), and can be found on the general coverage list and also on the covered company's page. A Catalyst Call represents a high- conviction belief by an analyst that a stock will outperform or underperform the market and/or a specified sector over a time frame of no less than two weeks and no more than three months. In addition to Catalyst Calls, analysts may occasionally discuss with our clients, and with Deutsche Bank salespersons and traders, trading strategies or ideas that reference catalysts or events that may have a near- term or medium- term impact on the market price of the securities discussed in this report, which impact may be directionally counter to the analysts' current 12- month view of total return or investment return as described herein. Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

Derivative transactions involve numerous risks including market, counterparty default and illiquidity risk. The appropriateness of these products for use by investors depends on the investors' own circumstances, including their tax position, their regulatory environment and the nature of their other assets and liabilities; as such, investors should take expert legal and financial advice before entering into any transaction similar to or inspired by the contents of this publication. The risk of loss in futures trading and options, foreign or domestic, can be substantial. As a result of the high degree of leverage obtainable in futures and options trading, losses may be incurred that are greater than the amount of funds initially deposited - up to theoretically unlimited losses. Trading in options involves risk and is not suitable for all investors. Prior to buying or selling an option, investors must review the 'Characteristics and Risks of Standardized Options", at https://www.theocc.com/company- information/documents- and- archives/publications. If you are unable to access the website, please contact your Deutsche Bank representative for a copy of this important document.

Participants in foreign exchange transactions may incur risks arising from several factors, including the following: (i) exchange rates can be volatile and are subject to large fluctuations; (ii) the value of currencies may be affected by numerous market factors, including world and national economic, political and regulatory events, events in equity and debt markets and changes in interest rates; and (iii) currencies may be subject to devaluation or government- imposed exchange controls, which could affect the value of the currency. Investors in securities such as ADRs, whose values are affected by the currency of an underlying security, effectively assume currency risk.

Unless governing law provides otherwise, all transactions should be executed through the Deutsche Bank entity in the investor's home jurisdiction. Aside from within this report, important conflict disclosures can also be found at https://research.db.com/Research/ on each company's research page. Investors are strongly encouraged to review this information before investing.

Backtested, hypothetical or simulated performance results have inherent limitations. Unlike an actual performance record based on trading actual client portfolios, simulated results are achieved by means of the retroactive application of a backtested model itself designed with the benefit of hindsight. Taking into account historical events the backtesting of performance also differs from actual account performance because an actual investment strategy may be adjusted any time, for any reason, including a response to material, economic or market factors. The backtested performance includes hypothetical results that do not reflect the reinvestment of dividends and other earnings or the deduction of advisory fees, brokerage or other commissions, and any other expenses that a client would have paid or actually paid. No representation is made that any trading strategy or account will or is likely to achieve profits or losses similar to those shown. Alternative modeling techniques or assumptions might produce significantly different results and prove to be more appropriate. Past hypothetical backtest results are neither an indicator nor guarantee of future returns. Actual results will vary, perhaps materially, from the analysis.

The method for computing individual E,S,G and composite ESG scores set forth herein is a novel method developed by the Research department within Deutsche Bank AG, computed using a systematic approach without human intervention. Different data providers, market sectors and geographies approach ESG analysis and incorporate the findings in a variety of ways. As such, the ESG scores referred to herein may differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other ESG data providers in the market and may also differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other divisions within the Deutsche Bank Group. Such ESG scores also differ from other ratings and rankings that have historically been applied in research reports published by Deutsche Bank AG. Further, such ESG scores do not represent a formal or official view of Deutsche Bank AG.

It should be noted that the decision to incorporate ESG factors into any investment strategy may inhibit the ability to participate in certain investment opportunities that otherwise would be consistent with your investment objective and other principal investment strategies. The returns on a portfolio consisting primarily of sustainable investments may be lower or higher than portfolios where ESG factors, exclusions, or other sustainability issues are not considered, and the investment opportunities available to such portfolios may differ. Companies may not necessarily meet high performance standards on all aspects of ESG or sustainable investing issues; there is also no guarantee that any company will meet expectations in connection with corporate responsibility, sustainability, and/or impact performance.
